title: victorian type
content:
Hi Everyone,

I need the most ornamented, over the top Victorian type you can possibly imagine. Any suggestions?

Thanks!  
Christine
author: waterytart

comments.content:
[Kilkenny](http://web.archive.org/web/20141002102410/http:/www.p22.com/ihof/kilkenny.html) of course!

It's yummy!  
 Check out all the swash stuff... buy the OpenType version.  
Check out all the glyphs in the Pro version here:  
 [http://new.myfonts.com/fonts/ihof/p22-kilkenny/regular/characters.html](http://web.archive.org/web/20141002102410/http:/new.myfonts.com/fonts/ihof/p22-kilkenny/regular/characters.html "http://new.myfonts.com/fonts/ihof/p22-kilkenny/regular/characters.html")  
(You might have to wait a bit for all the characters to load.)

Thanks John,

I love Kilkenny, but its still not as ornamental as I require, I'm afraid. I need it to be total overkill, kind of like this:

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20141002102410im_/http:/typophile.com/files/NO_4977.gif)

... or even more insane, if that's possible. I know a lot of this kind of lettering isn't digitized, so I've had a hard time finding what I need.

I ran into this a few minutes ago: [http://new.myfonts.com/fonts/michaelbrowers/geistig/](http://web.archive.org/web/20141002102410/http:/new.myfonts.com/fonts/michaelbrowers/geistig/ "http://new.myfonts.com/fonts/michaelbrowers/geistig/")

They are monograms but perhaps with a little doctoring you can get what you're looking for.

I have an old book of letterpress type/ornaments with a lot of this stuff, including whole alphabets. There must be books in a library near you with this, perhaps a scan or a good photocopy would get you going? The original copyright would most likely be expired and if you set your own text with the letters (rather than reproducing a whole page of the book), you would (caveat: I'm not a lawyer, please check) not breach the publisher's copyright on the book.

Try browsing through the offerings here:  
 [http://new.myfonts.com/foundry/Intellecta\_Design/](http://web.archive.org/web/20141002102410/http:/new.myfonts.com/foundry/Intellecta_Design/ "http://new.myfonts.com/foundry/Intellecta\_Design/")

Also, would Restraint work? The letters aren't ornate, but still...  
 [http://www.tiro.com/Restraint/index.html](http://web.archive.org/web/20141002102410/http:/www.tiro.com/Restraint/index.html "http://www.tiro.com/Restraint/index.html")

I second John’s suggestion.  
Some examples:  
 [http://new.myfonts.com/fonts/intellecta/surrey/](http://web.archive.org/web/20141002102410/http:/new.myfonts.com/fonts/intellecta/surrey/ "http://new.myfonts.com/fonts/intellecta/surrey/")  
 [http://new.myfonts.com/fonts/intellecta/bruce-flourished/](http://web.archive.org/web/20141002102410/http:/new.myfonts.com/fonts/intellecta/bruce-flourished/ "http://new.myfonts.com/fonts/intellecta/bruce-flourished/")  
 [http://new.myfonts.com/fonts/intellecta/victorian-ornamental-capitals/](http://web.archive.org/web/20141002102410/http:/new.myfonts.com/fonts/intellecta/victorian-ornamental-capitals/ "http://new.myfonts.com/fonts/intellecta/victorian-ornamental-capitals/")

Thanks all for your help everyone.

I was looking for the type because I wanted a reference point for a very embellished monogram. I still haven't found exactly what I'm looking for, but I think I'm going to turn to books with old type... I've found some beautiful stuff there.
